Description: Terracotta figure of a musician. A musician, standing with his knees slightly bent, and tilting his head to blow into panpipes. He wears a short chiton and has a conical hat with a knob on top and a wavy brim, upon which is set a closely woven wreath. Under his left arm is held the windbag of a set of bagpipes; the chanter crosses his body at waist level to be held by his right hand. An unidentified object is placed between his lower legs. Solid; pressed into a one-piece mould, the edges pared and the rear of the figure left rough and plain. Micaceous orange-brown Nile silt. On the front are traces of a white dressing; on the chiton are minute vestiges of pink paint. Ptolemaic, second or first century bc.
Curator's comments: BM Terracotta IV Comparanda. Close: Fischer 1994: no. 988, dated end of second, beginning of third century ad = Vogt 1924: pl. lxxix:1. Near, but the head very different: Hickmann 1960: pl. iii:2; Ewigleben and von Grumbkow 1991: no. 98; Schmidt 1997: no. 109, dated third century ad. Compare also another festival musician with conical hat, bagpipes and syrinx, but otherwise very different: Weber 1914: pl. 30:324. Bibliog. Fischer 1994: 385, no. 988.
Bibliographic references: Terracotta / Catalogue of Terracottas in the British Museum (3200)
Condition: His feet are lost at the ankles and have been restored in plaster; the chanter is damaged.
Acquisition name: Donated by: Sir William Matthew Flinders Petrie
